executive_summary: Rising rates of hearing loss from an aging population have supported hearing aid sales in recent years. At the same time, innovative tech advances improve the sound quality, aesthetics and comfort of hearing aids, broadening their appeal. Still, US-based manufacturing facilities have struggled. Import penetration has risen – an outcome of companies shifting US production facilities to countries where labor is more affordable. COVID-19 exacerbated volatility as manufacturers confronted a disrupted global supply chain, heightened input costs, weak demand and a strong US dollar. Hearing sales lost steam in 2022 again as inflation hurt consumers' wallets, but a massive regulatory change beginning at the tail end of 2022 reversed these trends.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Incidences of hearing loss increase with age
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: According to the National Institutes of Health, nearly half of people 75 and older have hearing difficulties. An aging population and longer life expectancies are growing the size of this market, expanding the need for hearing aids.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Older adults interested in managing their care
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Older adults are more interested in managing their care than previous generations, as they're more affluent, better educated and more engaged in wellness.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers cater to different price points
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Some hearing aid manufacturers cater to this demographic by offering new hearing aids to appeal to different price points and preferences. Lower price points can appeal to patients on fixed incomes, while others may value aids that offer valuable improvements in quality or comfort.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Lack of insurance coverage creates cost barriers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Medicare doesn't cover hearing aids or hearing exams. A lack of insurance coverage creates steep cost barriers, so introducing lower-priced hearing aids can be an attractive option for this age group. Still, without Medicare coverage, many adults don't look into adopting hearing aids.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: How the new FDA ruling will take shape remains unclear
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) new regulations took effect in 2022 but will continue to materialize and evolve throughout the hearing aid industry in the following years. The opening of the over-the-counter (OTC) hearing aid market will introduce more opportunities than ever but also open the door to unprecedented competitive and pricing pressures.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An aging's population medical needs pose an enormous market opportunity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Incidence of age-related hearing loss will expand as the population ages moving forward. Hearing aid manufacturers will be vital in providing solutions to hearing loss. Nearly 99.0% of older adults struggling with hearing loss could find a solution in OTC hearing aids, according to experts at John Hopkins, creating enormous market opportunities.

A more competitive market will fuel innovation. Hearing aid manufacturers that don't invest in research and development will lag behind competitors in delivering sound, comfort and quality improvements.

industry_definition: Hearing aid manufacturers are companies engaged in designing, producing and distributing hearing aids. These devices are specialized electronic instruments designed to assist individuals with hearing impairments by amplifying sound, making it easier for them to hear and communicate.

positive_impact_factors: High - steady barriers to entry level

opportunities: Number of adults aged 65 and older

key_trends: Hearing aid manufacturers can differentiate through price or quality.
Budget-conscious consumers want affordable OTC hearing aids, while others look for devices delivering the newest advances in hearing aid tech.
Tech advances are quickly improving the aesthetics and quality of hearing aids. Manufacturers that offer hearing aid users a better fit or sound quality can differentiate from competitors.
Domestic manufacturing facilities struggle as import penetration rises. Hearing aid manufacturers have shifted US facilities abroad to take advantage of lower-cost labor, heightening competition.
New regulations by the FDA are transforming the landscape of hearing aid manufacturing.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Individuals aged 44 and younger are the smallest market for hearing aid manufacturers due to low rates of hearing loss in this age group.
Since hearing loss rates increase with age, adults between 45 to 64 rely on hearing aids more than their younger counterparts. Tech advances may incentivize this demographic to adopt hearing aids.
Individuals aged 65 to 79 are a primary market for hearing aid manufacturers. Fast-growth in the size of this group is quickly making this one of the most lucrative markets for the industry.
Individuals aged 80 and up are the largest market for hearing aid manufacturers. Adults 80 and over have the highest incidence of age-related hearing loss.

products_and_services.product_description: Receiver-in-the-canal (RIC) and receiver-in-the-ear (RITE) hearing aids are designed for people with mild to severe hearing loss.
Behind-the-ear (BTE) hearing aids are a solution for people with mild to profound hearing loss.
Custom hearing aids are custom-made to fit inside the inside ear canal. This includes in-the-canal (ITC) and completely-in-canal (CIC) hearing aids.
A cochlear implant is an electronic device that provides hearing to individuals with severe to profound hearing loss.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Older adults have the highest incidences of hearing loss. Since hearing aids are the most common solution to hearing loss, a growing number of adults 65 and older increases demand for hearing aid manufacturing.
Tech advances may incentivize adults aged 45 to 64 to adopt hearing aids as advancements have made hearing aids more effective and discreet.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Poland is the largest importer of domestic hearing aids
international_trade_points.trade_description: Hearing aid manufacturers import more hearing aids to Poland than any other country; the country is the largest exporter of hearing aids globally, according to the Observatory of Economic Complexity.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Regulatory changes in the US prompt imports to increase
international_trade_points.trade_description: Hearing aid imports into the US will remain high moving forward. The FDA's policy ruling, which has been effective since 2022, allowing over-the-counter hearing aid sales is expected to increase imports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports weaken as production stays offshore
international_trade_points.trade_description: Just a handful of hearing aid manufacturers dominate this market. Of these, only one manufacturer, Starkey, is an American-owned company. Many manufacturers with US-based facilities have shifted their production to other countries to reduce production costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Germany is a fast-growing export market
international_trade_points.trade_description: The largest export markets for domestic hearing aid manufacturers include Germany, China, Canada and Mexico. Germany's share of hearing export sales from the US has been expanding the fastest.

business_locations.location_description: The West region has the highest percentage of both establishments (around 35%) and population (around 30%) compared to other regions.
The Southeast region has the second highest percentage of establishments (around 20%) and population (around 25%).
The Mid-Atlantic region has around 15% of establishments and population.
The Great Lakes region has around 10% of establishments and population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Hearing aids are classified as medical devices by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and are subject to the agency's regulations for medical devices.
The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) regulates advertising and marketing practices for hearing aids to ensure advertising is truthful and not misleading.
The American National Standards Institute (ANSI) plays a critical role in establishing standards that ensure the safety, reliability and performance of hearing aids.
The Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 directed the FDA to create a new category of hearing aids that can be sold over the counter without a prescription.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The hearing aid industry is mature.
There is a high level of technology change in the industry.
The industry has a high and increasing level of globalization.

factors_increased_barrier: The hearing aid industry is mature.
There is a high level of technology change in the industry.
The industry has a high and increasing level of globalization.
factors_decreased_barrier: The industry has a low level of capital intensity.

basis_points.basis_description: Hearing aid manufacturers can differentiate through price or quality.
Tech advances are quickly improving the aesthetics and quality of hearing aids.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Keeping up with mounting R&D expenses is critical but difficult for smaller companies.
A handful of major manufacturers like Demant and Starkey lead the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Raw Materials are the Main Factors Affecting Purchase
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Raw materials like plastic and resins are used to produce hearing aids. Volatility in the price of raw materials makes it difficult for manufacturers to manage purchase costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: COVID-19 exacerbated already volatile commodity markets
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Sudden changes in consumer needs and supply chain disruptions fueled volatility, making it difficult for manufacturers to accurately estimate and plan for material costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Supply chain challenges impacting hearing aid manufacturers have primarily resolved in 2024
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Supply chain challenges impacting hearing aid manufacturers have primarily resolved in 2024, keeping purchase expenses relatively steady.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Automation has replaced some aspects of hearing aid production, but the industry remains more labor-intensive than capital-intensive. A specialized workforce is necessary to maintain short- and long-run growth and innovation.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Stringent Controls on Medical Devices Create Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Regulations can affect the approval process for new types of hearing aids. Regulation changes can make it more difficult or expensive for manufacturers to bring new products to market.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumer Spending Patterns Influence Hearing Aid Sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: How much consumers spend on health devices influences demand for hearing aids and manufacturers' ability to research and develop new ones.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MANUFACTURERS INTEGRATE AI INTO HEARING AIDS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Hearing aid manufacturers are incorporating artificial intelligence (AI) into their products to improve sound quality and make hearing aids more adaptable to different listening environments.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Wireless Technology Improves Users' Experience with Hearing Aids
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Wireless technology can enable two hearing aids to work together as one collaborative system versus two independent devices.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Import penetration is very prominent in this industry. Hearing aid manufacturers benefit from a depreciating US dollar that makes their products more affordable at home and abroad.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: The company produces a diverse range of hearing aid products tailored to different consumer needs.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Companies have been moving manufacturing outside the country to areas with cheaper labor costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Shifts in the price of plastic impact profit. Manufacturers engaged in contracts with wholesalers can't always pass rising input costs downstream.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Companies have been implementing efficiency-increasing technologies to lower the time required to manufacture hearing aids and reduce labor costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Hearing aid manufacturing has a high level of technological innovations, and 3D printing has been incorporated for more efficient manufacturing processes.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The Hearing Industries Association advocates for hearing aid manufactures, and the Hearing Loss Association advertises the latest developments in the industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Because hearing aids are medical devices, they are regulated by the FDA and subject to agency approval. Cochlear implants require pre-market approval, while other hearing aids do not.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects requiring that require capital financing on the horizon?
FAQs.answer: The industry is fairly capital intensive, which raises the barrier to entry for potential new entrants.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Profit is sensitive to the cost of plastic, and fluctuations can cause profit declines.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Hearing aid manufacturers rely on technology, and new innovative products are developed at a rapid pace. To remain competitive, manufacturers must be able to innovate and incorporate new technology.

FAQs.question: How does your company work to develop new products? In what ways have you innovated your service offerings?
FAQs.answer: Hearing aid manufacturers need to offer new products at an affordable price is key to serving a broader section of the market and driving revenue growth.

FAQs.question: How do you insulate against the risk of price fluctuations? How closely do you monitor the fluctuations in exchange rates?
FAQs.answer: This is a highly globalized industry with many major companies operating as multinational corporations. Exchange rate fluctuations can change revenue and profit forecasts considerably.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How have fluctuations in the value of the US dollar affected demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index measures the relative strength of the US dollar. A strong US dollar makes US-made hearing aids more expensive at home and abroad.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor funding levels for Medicare and Medicaid?
FAQs.answer: While Medicare and Medicaid don't cover hearing aids, they may cover diagnostic hearing exams if a healthcare provider requests this test to determine medical treatment.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your clients are aged 65 and older? Do you advertise in areas that are frequented by people aged 65 and older?
FAQs.answer: According to the National Institute on Deafness and other Communication Disorders (NIDCD), one-third of Americans aged 65 to 74 and one-half of those 75 and older have some degree of hearing loss.
